stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on Course 15, a space-themed factory level. The stream focused on two main activities: first, refining the level's visuals, particularly a difficult reflective wall texture; and second, extensively brainstorming and designing the mechanics, narrative, and arena for the level's main boss, a large mutated Yoshi.

development_findings.summary: Kaze worked through a technical and artistic challenge to create a reflective surface, ultimately deciding against environment mapping to preserve the ability to use a detail texture.
development_findings.quote: I'm trying to make this look somewhat reflective without actually using an nth map because if I use an nth map I can't use a texture and if I can't use a texture then there's no detail and looks like shit.

development_findings.summary: The public demo for Course 1 was intentionally limited in scope to gather specific feedback on core mechanics and to avoid revealing too much of the game prematurely.
development_findings.quote: The purpose of the demo is to get feedback on Mario's physics and the camera... I did not want to reveal too much.

development_findings.summary: Kaze uses a classic graphical trick for the skybox, where it's a small 3D object that moves relative to the camera to create the illusion of a vast, distant space.
development_findings.quote: The skybox here, including the moon. It's actually super small... it just starts at where the camera is, and then it moves with the camera, but like 99% of the cameras movement.

development_findings.summary: Kaze identified that using a 4-bit intensity (i4) texture was causing noticeable color banding on the reflective surfaces, a technical limitation he had to work around.
development_findings.quote: I think the reason it's so bad is because we use an i4 texture and i4 only has 16 substeps so you'd see all this color bending.

development_findings.summary: A core design principle for the game is maintaining the consistency of Mario's physics, avoiding power-ups or scenarios that fundamentally alter the core gameplay.
development_findings.quote: One important ground rule for this is that most of the time you will stay Mario and up with the same physics that's important for me.

development_findings.summary: A user named 'Asa' provided a texture for the factory walls that Kaze ultimately used and preferred over his own attempts.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's primary motivation is not financial but the creative desire to make an interesting game on original N64 hardware.
context_findings.quote: I just want to make a cool N64 game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels intense pressure and has had negative interactions with the SM64 PC port community, leading him to actively avoid using it for his projects.
context_findings.quote: People have been so insistent and annoying about the PC port. That at this point, out of pure stubbornness, I want nothing to do with it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses anxiety about his unedited, more personal second YouTube channel gaining a large audience, highlighting a tension between his public persona and private self.
context_findings.quote: I'm a little scared that there's too many people watching my second channel because it's just like me posting whatever the fuck I feel like and there's like no editing or anything it's like too private for the public you know.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes many games simplify boss fights to ranged attacks because creating meaningful, direct physical interaction is too difficult, a challenge he aims to overcome.
context_findings.quote: I feel like a lot of boss fights work in a similar way. But making the player interact with the boss in a way that doesn't suck balls is too difficult. So they just do that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze jokes about being paranoid of Nintendo's reaction to his work, humorously suggesting he'd be murdered if he ever worked for them, which hints at an awareness of the legally precarious nature of his projects.
context_findings.quote: I wouldn't be able to trust them. You know, I would think that as soon as I accept that and like walk into office, I get like killed at work. They will just murder me.

biobak.summary: Biobak is actively involved in the conceptual design phase of the Course 15 boss fight.
biobak.quote: me and Biobak we have been talking about a little bit the boss fight is basically the thing we have to like do next or plan out next.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided concept art or a written idea for the boss, specifically endorsing the concept of a 'tentacle yoshi'.
biobak.quote: Biobak did draw something here but he sent me this idea here before that's like a thing in yoshi's island go read that he said i'm 100% down for a tentacle yoshi.

key_stories.title: The Mutated Yoshi Boss Concept
key_stories.summary: Kaze workshopped the design for the Course 15 boss, a mutated Yoshi. After struggling with a conventional combat concept, a suggestion to 'heal' the boss by destroying its tumors led to a creative breakthrough, defining the entire encounter's narrative and mechanical direction.
key_stories.challenge: How to design a compelling boss fight for the space factory level.
key_stories.process: Kaze and Biobak initially conceived of a mutated 'tentacle Yoshi'. During the stream, Kaze brainstormed attack patterns like ground pounds and tongue attacks but struggled with the core objective. A chat suggestion sparked the idea of healing the Yoshi, which Kaze immediately embraced as it aligned better with the lore where Yoshis are friends. He then fleshed out the full fight, including attack patterns, weaknesses, and how supporting enemies would teach the mechanic.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze pivoted from a traditional 'kill the boss' concept to a 'heal the boss' concept. The player will cure a mutated Yoshi by destroying its pulsating tumors, after which the Yoshi will be thankful and leave peacefully. This narrative twist provides a more unique and emotionally resonant goal.
key_stories.key_quote: Okay, wait, let's let's think about that one. So there okay, what if you just destroy the tumors and that like makes him happy and he's like wow, thanks for helping me... That's a bang idea. I think we'll do that.

key_stories.title: The Reflective Wall Texture
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to create a specific visual effect for the factory walls. After his own attempts failed to meet his standards, he found success by using a texture provided by a community member, highlighting the role of external feedback and collaboration in his process.
key_stories.challenge: Creating a convincing reflective texture for the factory walls without using an environment map, which would sacrifice detail.
key_stories.process: Kaze spent a significant amount of time trying to create a scrolling, reflective texture. He experimented with texture size, brightness, and contrast, but was unhappy with the results, calling his own concept 'shit'. He looked at an example from another creator, 'Dario', for inspiration before trying a texture sent by 'Asa' in the chat, which finally worked.
key_stories.outcome: After much trial and error, Kaze implemented a texture provided by a user named 'Asa' which achieved the desired look. He was pleased with the result but humorously frustrated that he couldn't solve it on his own.
key_stories.key_quote: oh it is kind of nice i have to admit dang oh but you made it to 64 by 64 so i guess it has to be an i8 here... so yeah that's way nicer than what i had before but why i don't understand why is this better.

key_stories.title: Frustration with the PC Port Community
key_stories.summary: Kaze detailed his frustration with the SM64 PC port community, explaining how their constant pressure and negative comments have led him to deliberately and stubbornly avoid the platform, even if it were beneficial.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze feels constant pressure and antagonism from the SM64 PC port community, which affects his development choices.
key_stories.process: Kaze recounted his negative experiences with the PC port community, including being called jealous or unskilled. He used a detailed analogy about Formula 1 racing to explain his frustration at being expected to work on a platform he is not interested in, when his goal is simply to make a game for the N64.
key_stories.outcome: Due to the persistent and, in his view, 'insufferable' nature of the community's demands, Kaze has adopted a stance of 'pure stubbornness' and refuses to engage with or develop for the PC port.
key_stories.key_quote: Imagine you as a normal person... while you drive your car, all the time people come up to you and be like, why aren't you doing Formula 1 racing? And that's just happening every single day to you.
